snippet: Amid a rift among officers and Mayor Bill de Blasio, Patrick J. Lynch is beating back dissent within his Patrolmen’s Benevolent Association as he seeks a fifth term as president.
abstract: Patrick J Lynch, controversial president of Patrolmen's Benevolent Assn, is battling to contain insurgent campaign against his leadership amid rift between New York Police Dept and New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio; tension erupts into shouting match at union luncheon in Queens, even as Lynch seeks support for his fifth four-year term; incident highlights internal clashes reemerging between leaders of the city's five police unions.

byline.original: By AL BAKER and J. DAVID GOODMAN
byline.contributor: Michael M. Grynbaum and Thomas Kaplan contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: Amid a rift among officers and Mayor Bill de Blasio, Patrick J. Lynch is beating back dissent within his Patrolmen’s Benevolent Association as he seeks a fifth term as president.

headline.main: President of New York City Police Union Faces Internal Opposition
headline.print_headline: Trying to Heal Rifts, Police Now Face an Internal One
